div.p: Owing to abundant spectrum resources, millimeter wave (mmwave) communication promises to provide Gbps data rates, which, however, may be restricted by large path-loss. Thus, antenna arrays are commonly used along with beam alignment (BA) as an important step to achieve the array gain. Efficient BA relies on the beam training codebook design. In this paper, we propose a new hierarchical codebook to achieve uniform BA performance with low overhead. To better elaborate on the design principle, a single-path channel model is considered first to frame the proposal. The codebook design is formulated as an optimization problem, where the ripple in the main/side lobes is constrained such that each training beam is close to the ideal one with a flat magnitude response and a narrow transition band. Then, we propose an efficient algorithm to find such a beam training codebook. Furthermore, we derive closed-form expressions of the BA misalignment probability or error rate of the proposed beam training codebook. Our results reveal that using the proposed codebook, the error rate of tree-searchbased BA exponentially decreases with the SNR for a given channel, and linearly decreases in the log-log coordinate axis for a fading channel. We further propose a power allocation scheme used in different training stages to further improve the BA performance. Finally, the proposed framework is extended to the more complex case of multi-path channels. Numerical results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed training codebook and power allocation scheme as well as the accuracy of the performance analysis.

Considering the fact that an mmwave radiofrequency (RF) chain is expensive and its ADC/DAC is power consuming, a hybrid structure is preferred, where the number of RF chains is far less than that of antennas [8], [9]. This brings new challenges for the design of hybrid digital/analog beamforming [10].

Note that due to possible large path-loss, the receive signal of mmwave communication may be too weak to work before effective beamforming. It is important to align the transmit and receive beams at the very beginning of communication, so as to achieve the array gain. This procedure is commonly called as beam alignment (BA), realized by searching the best pairs of transmit and receive beams from a beam training codebook [11]- [13]. In general, BA with high accuracy plays a key role in building reliable mmwave communication links, achieving desired data of transmission and enlarging the cell coverage area. Particularly, accurate BA techniques can be used for mmwave channel estimation, i.e., by estimating relevant physical parameters including angle of arrival (AoA) and path gain [14], [15].

In practical mmwave communication systems, there are stringent requirements on BA. First, high frequencies of mmwave bands imply that the channels may vary quickly, and BA shall be completed in a small portion of the channel coherent time. Hence, an exhaustive beam search is inapplicable. Second, to fully exploit the array gain of large antenna arrays, the aligned beams need to be narrow, which increases the complexity of BA and thus calls for highly efficient codebook designs and beam search algorithms.

To reduce the training overhead of BA, an efficient approach is to use a tree search algorithm based on a hierarchical multi-resolution codebook [14], [16]- [19]. The hierarchical codebook is defined with different levels of sub-codebooks. In the high level, the sub-codebook consists of a small number of low-resolution beams (coarse beams), covering the intended angle/beam range. In the lower level, the sub-codebook has an increased number of fine beams to cover the same angle/beam range. The width or coverage of each coarse beam is identical to the aggregated width of multiple finer beams together. Then, a search-and-refine algorithm can be carried out across the hierarchical codebook. It should be noted that there is error propagation in a binary tree search, which can reduce the BA performance. Recently, the BA performance of hierarchical search (in terms of the asymptotic misalignment probability) was analyzed in [20] via large deviations. It was pointed out in [20] that a desirable training beam for BA shall have a uniform gain in the main lobe.

Since the hierarchical codebook design is crucial in improving the BA performance, it has attracted much attention recently. In [17], the hierarchical-search-based BA technique was proposed to overcome the outdoor impairments in millimeter wave propagation. A hierarchical codebook design based on the least squares (LS) method was proposed in [14] to estimate mmwave channels. By jointly exploiting sub-array and deactivation antenna processing techniques, a hierarchical codebook design was devised in [16], where the closed-form expressions were provided to generate the codebook. The deactivation antenna processing technique was also used in [18] to design hierarchical codebooks. However, turning off antennas is not a good approach for broader beam designs since each antenna typically has an active power amplifier and the efficiency of power amplifiers at mmwave frequencies is also poor. Moreover, turning off antennas will lead to a loss of the array gain and collective EIRP levels due to a smaller number of active antennas.

In general, the training beams designed by the approaches mentioned above usually have a large ripple in main/side lobes. Note that it is important to control the ripple of training beams. Firstly, suppressing the ripple is beneficial to achieve a uniform BA performance, i.e., the BA performance (e.g., the achieved conditional BA misalignment probability) is independent of the angles of arrival and departure (AoA and AoD) of the user channel, which can guarantee user fairness to some extent. Secondly, suppressing the ripple is also beneficial to reduce the BA error rate. Although the authors in [14] realized the importance of controlling the ripple, the proposed LS method cannot well suppress the ripple and thus causes a large performance loss on non-quantized points in the angle domain. In the study of beamforming tradeoffs for initial UE discovery, a maximin optimization design was proposed to achieve a well-shaped training beam, which essentially looks for a flat array gain response in the coverage area of the designed beam, and thus can achieve a small ripple in the main lobe as well as side lobe in most cases [21]. Nevertheless, to design an effective hierarchical training codebook, it is crucial to strictly control the ripples of the main/side lobes in each beam codeword.
Although some design insights are available [20], [21], the original fundamental problems have not yet been solved, and meanwhile new practical problems arise. They include:

(1) how to design a training beam with guaranteed narrow transition band and small ripples in both the main lobe and the side lobe; (2) if such training beams are available, how to assess the BA performance more accurately and comprehensively, especially for practical parameter setting; (3) what extra benefits and insights can we obtain using the designed training beams? (4) how to address the error propagation and to achieve a desirable BA performance; (5) using the designed training beams, can we further improve the BA performance?

In this paper, inspired by the former works [14], [16]- [21], we propose a training codebook design by shaping the geometric pattern of each beam and formulating the beam design as an optimization problem with both the ripple and the transition band taken into consideration. The designed training beam with arbitrary beamwidth is optimized to possess a flat magnitude response and a narrow transition band. To address the error propagation, we modify the codebook structure based on the method of the proposed training beam design. We further derive the analytic expressions of the achieved BA performance and provide some useful insights. In particular, the use of the designed codebooks is able to achieve a uniform BA performance. Based on the derived concise expressions, we further propose an efficient strategy for allocating training resource to further improve the BA performance. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:
• To obtain the desirable beam pattern, we formulate the training beam design as a beam pattern optimization problem, with the constraints on the ripple of main/side lobes and the transition band.

• Then, we propose an efficient method to address the nonconvex beam pattern optimization problem. The obtained beam has a small ripple in both the main/side lobes and a narrow transition band. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. We present the system model in Section II. The codebook structure and design guidance are presented in Section III. The beam pattern shaping approach and transition band processing are proposed in Section IV and Section V, respectively. The performance analysis and some extension are presented in Section VI and Section VII, respectively. Simulation results are provided in Section VIII. Conclusions are draw in Section IX.

div.head: II. SYSTEM MODEL
div.p: We consider a multiple-input single-output (MISO) communication system operating in the mmwave spectrum. The transmitter (Tx) is equipped with N t transmit antennas, which are controlled by N rf RF chains, and the receiver (Rx) has a single antenna. Accounting for practical limitation on the mmwave hardware, it is assumed that the RF analog phase shifters have constant modulus and the number of RF chains is limited, i.e., N rf < N t . We first focus on the MISO case as it is easier to understand and illustrate the principle of codebook design and simplify the performance analysis. Later on, we extend our design to the MIMO case.

An extended Saleh-Valenzuela geometric model was adopted in the literature [21]- [27]. In the ideal setting, the channel is determined by scattering over several clusters/paths with no near-field impairments at the receiver end. In this paper, the channel vector is given by

div.p: In this section, we first present the codebook structure and the corresponding BA algorithm. Then, we derive the guidance for the codebook design with the objective of minimizing the BAER.

div.head: B. Iterative Algorithm
div.p: Now we focus on solving the formulated optimization problem. Observing that problem ( 15) is non-convex due to the first constraint, thus it is challenging to find its globally optimal solution. Here we use constrained concave-convex procedure (CCCP) [30] to tackle this problem.

The CCCP is an iterative algorithm, whose kernel step is first forming a convex problem by linearizing the non-convex part of the constrains at the current iteration and then its solution yields the next iteration. If the constraint function of the resultant convex problem is an upper bound of the original constraint function, the sequence generated by the CCCP keeps the objective function nonincreasing and its limit point is a stationary point under a suitable constraint qualification condition.

div.p: The analysis above indicates that if the real AoD locates in the transition band of some beamforming vector, the designed codebook using the conventional hierarchical structure may still suffer from a performance loss. div.head: B. BA Performance
div.p: The simulation setting is given as follows. The average path-loss β in ( 1) is assumed to be 1. The AoD ϕ takes continuous values in [-π/2, π/2] uniformly. The tree search consists of S = log 2 N t training stages. The width of transition band 2δ is set to be 2/N t , i.e., δ = 1/N t . Besides the BMW-SS codebook, another codebook designed by the beam shape synthesis method (BSSM) in [35] is also considered for comparison. To be fair in comparison with the BA based on different codebooks, we restrict that the total training powers for the comparing schemes are equal. We use the metric P fail or Pfail to evaluate the performance of BA using different training codebooks. The simulation results are obtained by averaging over 10 8 independent channel realization for each SNR value defined in (28).

We first consider single-path and fixed-gain mmwave channels and adopt the equal power allocation strategy. Fig. 6(a) shows the average BAER of hierarchical search with the BMW-SS, BSSM and BPSA codebooks. The results show that the BAER performance with our BPSA codebook is better than that with the BMW-SS or BSSM codebook when the SNR is greater than -2dB. As the SNR increases, the BAER with the three codebooks all decreases. However, the BAER with the BPSA codebook decreases dramatically, while the BAER with the other codebooks decreases gently. Particularly, the BAER with the BPSA codebook decays exponentially in the SNR, which agrees with the result derived in Corollary 1. The reason is two-fold. Firstly, the training beams generated by Algorithm 2 have narrower transition band and small ripple in main/side lobes. Secondly, since the transition band of training beamforming vectors within the BPSA codebook is processed carefully, a uniform BA performance in the whole interval [-1, 1] can be achieved. One can also observe that the upper bound provided by Theorem 2 is effective but not tight, however, the BAER expression provided by Theorem 1 is close to the numerical results over the whole SNR range. Moreover, it is interesting to see that the expression derived in Corollary 1 is also effective though a couple of approximations are adopted in the derivation. The average BAER of hierarchical search with the three codebooks for single-path fading channels is shown in Fig. 6(b). "Equal" and "Optimized" in the legend represent the equal power allocation strategy and the optimized power allocation strategy derived in Corollary 3, respectively. One can observe that for either of the two strategies the BAER of the BPSA codebook is lower than that of the BMW-SS codebook or the BSSM codebook over all SNRs. Moreover, the BAER performance of the optimized power allocation strategy derived in Corollary 3 is better than that of the equal power allocation strategy. It is also observed that the BAER decreases almost linearly with the SNR in the log-log coordinate axis. This result is consistent with the analytical one given in (46).

Next we consider the BAER performance of multi-path mmwave channels, where the number of paths, i.e., L in (1), is 3 and the number of beams to be aligned L 0 is also 3. The channel paths are assumed to be apart from each other. For the multi-path model, if one path fails to achieve predefined accuracy, BA is regarded failed. The average BAER and spectral efficiency of hierarchical search with the three codebooks for fading channels are shown in Fig. 7(a) and Fig. 7(b), respectively. The thin dash lines in Fig. 7(a) denote the probability that at most one path fails.

It is observed from Fig. 7(a) that the BAER performance of the BPSA codebook is better than that of the BMW-SS or BSSM codebook. Interestingly, one can observe from Fig. 7(a) that it is difficult to align all beams successfully for multi-path fading channels, since the gains of some paths may be very small. However, it is still able to align most of the paths with a high probability, as shown by the thin dash lines. Fig. 7(a) also shows the superiorities of the proposed power allocation strategy for multi-path fading channels. Since the BPSA codebook can achieve better BAER performance, as expected, the spectral efficiency of hierarchical search with the BPSA codebook is better than that of the BMW-SS or BSSM codebook, as shown in Fig. 7(b).

div.head: IX. CONCLUSION
div.p: We first derived the guidance for codebook design with the aim to achieving a uniform BA performance. From the perspective of shaping the pattern of a training beam, especially controlling its ripple, we formulated the hierarchical codebook design into a non-convex optimization problem. Then, we reached an efficient solution to the problem which converged to a KKT point. The simulation results showed that our designed beam has flat main/sibe lobes and a controllable transition band. To address the error propagation, we proposed a modified hierarchical codebook structure, which helped to achieve the uniform BA performance and caused ignorable extra overhead when the number of antennas is large. Using the designed training codebook, we analyzed the achievable performance of the binary-tree-search-based BA in terms of BAER, and derived closed-form approximate expressions for both fixed-gain channels and fading channels. The effectiveness was verified via numerical results. They revealed that the BAER of the BA using our designed codebook decreases exponentially with the SNR for fixed-gain channels while decreases linearly in the log-log coordinate axis for fading channels. To further improve the BA performance, we proposed a power allocation scheme. Finally, simulation results were provided to demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed algorithms under different channel environments, which almost coincided with our analytical results.
